The S3 class system

Mar 21, 2017 • Amy Crawford

Explain how a user can define a new S3 class with objects and methods at a small example of your choice.

We know that R treats everything like an object. One common attribute associated with an object is its class, and a user can set the class attribute using the class() command. Understanding these basics, a user can define a new S3 class by writing a function that creates an object of a certain class, and returns a copy. The following example will demonstrate how a user can create an object of class type S3 and define methods. First, I create a list and set defaults for data entries that are stored in the list. I then procede to set the class.

Now, I can create objects of class Cupcake by calling the function.

Now I can create methods that are associated with the Cupcakes class. The methods are defined in a generic way, then in a way that is very specific to the Cupcakes class.

Let’s take a look at how the function works! The object class is recognized and the correct function is used.

The object class is recognized and the correct function is used.
